title: Accessing Digital Traces via Data Donations

title: Accessing Digital Traces via Data Donations
text:
About the workshop

üíª Method Workshop as part of the Annual Conference of the Media Reception and Effects Division of the DGPuK
üìÖ January 21st, 2026 (11:15 am to 5 pm)
üìç University of Klagenfurt (Universit√§tsstr. 90, first floor, H√∂rsaal 5)
Workshop led by: Valerie Hase (Digital Media and Methods Lab, University of Klagenfurt). Partly funded by the DFG project ‚ÄúIntegrating Data Donations in Survey Infrastructure‚Äù
Organization: Young Scholar Network of the Media Reception and Effects Division of the DGPuK, special shout out üôå to Alicia Ernst & Ulrike Schwertberger. Big thanks also to the local organization team at the University of Klagenfurt!

title: Accessing Digital Traces via Data Donations
text:
Workshop Summary
Digital trace data ‚Äì records of activities on digital platforms created as people use them ‚Äì offer fine-grained, time-stamped, and often longitudinal measurements. Data donation studies are a new method for collecting these traces: users download their data from platforms under the GDPR‚Äôs right to data portability and donate them to researchers. Researchers then use computational methods to filter, preprocess, and analyze the data in a privacy-by-design approach. In particular, data donation enables the collection of less reactive, highly longitudinal data.
This workshop introduces data donation studies. After a general introduction to digital traces and user-centric methods (e.g., data donation, passive tracking, sensors), we will dive into the key steps of data donation studies from both participant and researcher perspectives. In the workshop, you will assess downloaded data packages, learn how to use them to study social science phenomena, and consider their inherent biases. In addition, we will discuss technical, theoretical, legal, and ethical considerations of data donation studies.

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
text:
What is digital trace data?
Definition üí°: The recording and storing of activities on digital platforms to draw conclusions about digital and analog phenomena

e.g., tweets, likes, shares on social media
e.g., geo data (locations, movements)
e.g., digital payments
e.g., Spotify playlists

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo

Example: Instagram Like

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo

What is digital trace data?

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
text:
Which systems/sensors collect traces?

Apps & social media platforms (e.g., Instagram)
Payment systems (e.g., Paypal)
Wearable devices (e.g., smart watch, fitbit)
Governmental databases (e.g., health data)

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
section: Which types of data does this include?
text:
Which types of data does this include?
Depending on the data collection method‚Ä¶ (Haim & Hase, 2023; Ohme et al., 2024):

often fine-grained (e.g., time-stamped)
often longitudinal (e.g., over years, within-individual change)
often less reactive (e.g., less concerns about social desirability)

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
section: Which types of data does this include?
text:
Which types of data does this include?

Source: Keusch & Kreuter, 2023, p.¬†102

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
section: What (latent) phenomena are we trying to explain?
text:
What (latent) phenomena are we trying to explain?



How (often) people use the internet/apps (Parry et al., 2021) ‚Ä¶


to explain well-being (Ohme et al., 2024) & sleep quality (Siebers et al., 2024)
to explain voting behavior (Bach et al., 2021)


What content people are exposed to ‚Ä¶


fake news (Lyons et al., 2024)
health-related info (Bachl et al., 2024)





Where and how people move to explain ‚Ä¶


mobility during pandemics (Li et al., 2021)
how deprived neighbourhoods can benefit from green spaces (Pawlowski et al., 2019)


Career trajectories / financial behavior ‚Ä¶


how relationships affect womens‚Äô earnings (M√∂hring & Weiland, 2022)
whether overqualification can lead to wage loss (Kracke et al., 2018)

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
section: Why are digital traces becoming more popular?
text:
Why are digital traces becoming more popular?

Problems with self-reported data (e.g., via survey)

‚ÄúHow many minutes a day do you use the internet to consume news?‚Äù

Source: Image by Scott Graham via Unsplash

‚Äûinternet‚Äù?
‚Äûnews‚Äù?
‚Äûhow many minutes‚Äù?

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
section: Why are digital traces becoming more popular?
text:
Why are digital traces becoming more popular?

Problems with self-reported data (e.g., via survey)

Inaccurate measurements (recall issues)
Bias (Parry et al., 2021; Scharkow, 2016): individual characteristics may predict under- or overreporting
Declining response rates in surveys (Luiten et al., 2020)

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
section: Why are digital traces becoming more popular?
text:
Why are digital traces becoming more popular?

Problems with self-reported data (e.g., via survey)
Availability of digital traces

cheap (e.g., via APIs)
large data sets (‚Äúbig data‚Äù)
more accurate (‚Äúobjective data‚Äù)

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
section: Why are digital traces becoming more popular?
text:
Why are digital traces becoming more popular?

Problems with self-reported data (e.g., via survey)
Availability of digital traces

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
section: Why are digital traces becoming more popular?
text:
Why are digital traces becoming more popular?

Problems with self-reported data (e.g., via survey)
Availability of digital traces

Be careful: These ‚Äúadvantages‚Äù of traces are often claimed, but empirically disputed.
Digital traces are neither necessarily less biased, nor cheaper, or larger (we will discuss this in Session 4Ô∏è‚É£).

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
text:
(Dis-)advantages of digital trace data

‚úÖ More fine-grained, often longitudinal measures due to timestamps
‚úÖ Partly measurement of new variables (e.g., algorithmic inference)
‚ùå Still bias due to errors in representation and measurement
‚ùå Implementation can be expensive and cumbersome


üëâ More data does not mean better data!

text: Platform- and user-centric methods

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
text:
Platform- and user-centric methods


Platform-centric (based on platform cooperation)

API (J√ºnger, 2021)
Cooperation with platforms (Wagner, 2023)

User-centric (based on user cooperation and informed consent) or ‚Äúfollow the user‚Äù approaches (Caliandro, 2024)

Data donation (Carri√®re et al., 2024)
Linkage to existing databases (Sloan et al., 2020)
Active sharing via sensors (Struminskaya et al., 2021)
Passive sharing via sensors/tracking (Christner et al., 2022)

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
text: Platform- and user-centric methods

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
text:
Platform- and user-centric methods
Placeholder first data Elli

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
text:
Platform- and user-centric methods


Restrictions of platform-centric methods

Discontinuation of APIs (Freelon, 2018)
Concerns about bias (Schatto-Eckrodt, 2022; Ulloa et al., 2025)

User-centric methods become more popular, given ‚Ä¶

Legal frameworks enabling such studies (GDPR, DSA)
Presumably (!) more researcher control
Ethical considerations (informed consent)

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
section: Summary: How can we collect digital traces? üìö
text:
Summary: How can we collect digital traces? üìö

Summary

Platform-centric methods (e.g., APIs) and user-centric methods (e.g., data donation)
Key differences: control over samples & measurements, legal & ethical contexts

Further literature

Haim & Hase (2023)
Ohme et al. (2024)

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
text:
1) What are data donation studies?

Source: Image by Markus Winkler via Unsplash

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
text:
Changes in legal contexts


EU secures right to own data in Art. 15 of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)

‚ÄúThe data subject shall have [‚Ä¶] access to the personal data‚Äù (¬ß Art. 15, 1)
‚ÄúThe controller shall provide a copy of the personal data‚Äù (¬ß Art. 15, 3)

According to ¬ß Art. 20, users must receive their data ‚Äúin a structured, commonly used and machine-readable format‚Äù (¬ß Art. 20, 1)

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
text:
Changes in legal contexts

EU secures right to own data in Art. 15 of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)

‚ÄúThe data subject shall have [‚Ä¶] access to the personal data‚Äù (¬ß Art. 15, 1)
‚ÄúThe controller shall provide a copy of the personal data‚Äù (¬ß Art. 15, 3)

According to ¬ß Art. 20, users must receive their data ‚Äúin a structured, commonly used and machine-readable format‚Äù (¬ß Art. 20, 1)

üëâ Solution: Platforms offer data download packages (DDPs), which users can request and download to inspect data.
üëâ Consequence: Researchers uses DDPs as part of user-centric data donation studies.

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
text:
Please raise your hand ‚úã if you‚Ä¶
1) knew about this right?
2) ever tried to request your data?
ü§î

In Switzerland, only 8% of members of an online access panel did (Pfiffner & Friemel, 2023, p. 17)

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
text:
What are data donation studies?
Definition üí°: Data donation studies are a user-centric, privacy-by-design method for collecting digital traces:


Users have the right to request, access, and download data that platforms collect about them.
They can make their data packages (DDPs) available to science via data donation tools (DDTs), often in the context of surveys.
Researchers use CSS methods to filter, anonymize, and aggregate this data locally on participants‚Äô devices.
Participants can inspect/delete their data before any data is transferred.

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
section: Which types of data do DDPs contain?
text:
Which types of data do DDPs contain?
For platforms like Facebook, Instagram, or YouTube, for example‚Ä¶ (Hase et al., 2024)


User profiles (e.g., privacy settings)
Activities (e.g., friends, likes, searches, exposure, analog movements)
Content and context (e.g., ads watched, algorithmically inferred interests)

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
section: How is data from DDPs different?
text:
How is data from DDPs different?
Compared to APIs (Haim & Hase, 2023; Ohme et al., 2024)‚Ä¶

Control & informed consent of users
Longitudinal data without ‚Äúrate limits‚Äù
Partly more knowledge about missing data (e.g., unit drop-out)
Partly additional measurements (e.g., exposure data; non-public data)

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
section: How is data from DDPs different?
text:
How is data from DDPs different?
Compared to tracking (Haim & Hase, 2023; Ohme et al., 2024)‚Ä¶

Retrospective & often more longitudinal
Partly additional measurements (e.g., algorithmic inferences)
Anchored in current provisions in law (for issues with tracking, see Edelson & McCoy, 2021)

üëâ but similarly burdensome for participants!

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
section: Summary: What are data donation studies? üìö
text:
Summary: What are data donation studies? üìö

Summary: User-centric method for collecting digital traces: Users download their data packages (DDPs) from platforms and make them available to science via data donation tools (DDTs).
Further literature:

Boeschoten et al. (2022)
Carri√®re et al. (2024)

text:
2) Participant perspective

Source: Image by Markus Winkler via Unsplash

As data donation is really centered on the participant, we best start to understand data donation by taking their perspective.
You already did one part of this process before coming here: Requesting and downloading your data from YouTube, Instagram, or LinkedIn

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
text:
üì¢ Task 1: Inspect your DDPs.

Which variables can you identify?
How could you use these for research in your field?
What are questions you may have about these measurements?

Feel free to work in groups of 2-3 people (around 15 minutes)

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
text:
Step II: Download
Different degrees in standardization for DDP content (Hase et al., 2024)‚Ä¶
Documentation & changes over time

What does each file ‚Äúmean‚Äù?
How was this data measured?

Completeness & scope

Is data missing and, if so, why?
Why are some data points limited to specific time frames?
How do we handle multi-lingual DDPs?

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
text:
üì¢ Task 2: Try donating your data.
Upload and inspect your data. If you could not download the data, use the ZIP folder ‚Äúexample data‚Äù (see landing page) for this session.

Are there any surprising/missing values?
Did you encounter any difficulties in deleting/sharing your data?


Use this link: https://next.eyra.co/a/nWPJC4?p=999 - replace number after p= with random number. Feel free to work in groups of 2-3 people.

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
text:
üì¢ Task 3: Extract personality profiles from data.
Inspect the ZIP folder ‚Äúexample‚Äù data for this session (manually or upload it to the data donation study - data you see may then differ). Imagine you are a commercial company.
Based on the trace data, how would you profile this person in terms of‚Ä¶.

sociodemographic characteristics
their interests
ads you may target them with


Use this link: https://next.eyra.co/a/nWPJC4?p=999 - replace number after p= with random number. Feel free to work in groups of 2-3 people.

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
text:
Bias in Data Donation Studies
Similar to tracking studies, data donation characterized by (Hase et al., 2024; Hase & Haim, 2024; Keusch et al., 2024):

Errors in representation (e.g., coverage error, non-response error)
Measurement errors (e.g., missing data, specification error)

üëâ Not necessarily less biased than survey data - but subject to different bias?
üëâ We will talk about this in Session 4Ô∏è‚É£.

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
section: Informed Consent in Data Donation Studies
text:
Informed Consent in Data Donation Studies
Similar to tracking (Kreuter et al., 2020): Is consent really ‚Äúinformed‚Äù? (Groot Kormelink et al., 2025; Hase & Haim, 2024)

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
section: Informed Consent in Data Donation Studies
text:
Informed Consent in Data Donation Studies
Similar to tracking (Kreuter et al., 2020): Is consent really ‚Äúinformed‚Äù? (Groot Kormelink et al., 2025; Hase & Haim, 2024)

in walk-through interviews, participants ‚Äúfundamentally misunderstood [this] key principle‚Äù (p.¬†8)
Anecdotal evidence: sending data via email, sending different data, sending someone else‚Äôs data, etc.
Almost no one deletes data (except for searches!)

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
section: Step I.I Which questions do I want to answer?
text:
Step I.I Which questions do I want to answer?
Empirical studies on data donation focus on ‚Ä¶

exposure/pathways to news or political content (Loecherbach et al., 2024; Wojcieszak et al., 2023; Xuanjun Gong & Richard Huskey, 2023)
social interaction/relationship development (Brinberg & Ram, 2021; Corten et al., 2025; Virtanen et al., 2021)

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
section: Step I.I Which questions do I want to answer?
text:
Step I.I Which questions do I want to answer?
Research designs include ‚Ä¶


use of observational data to describe/explain (e.g., how platforms shape exposure diversity, often via sequential modeling) (Loecherbach et al., 2024)
combination with experimental designs (e.g., interventions, sock puppet training) (Yu et al., 2024)
triangulation with qualitative methods (e.g., walk-through-interviews) (Pierce-Grove & Watkins, 2024)

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
section: Step I.I Which questions do I want to answer?
text:
Step I.I Which questions do I want to answer?
Research designs include ‚Ä¶

use of observational data to describe/explain (e.g., how platforms shape exposure diversity, often via sequential modeling) (Loecherbach et al., 2024)
combination with experimental designs (e.g., interventions, sock puppet training) (Yu et al., 2024)
triangulation with qualitative methods (e.g., walk-through-interviews) (Pierce-Grove & Watkins, 2024)

‚ö†Ô∏è Causal inference remains a key problem!
‚ö†Ô∏è Match between theoretical concepts and measurements remains a key problem!

Participants ‚Äúupload‚Äù data (nothing is send anywhere)
Local extraction, anonymization, & aggregation
Users can delete data
Informed consent, only then: send to researcher server

Next (Boeschoten et al., 2023) (different measurements, different platforms)
Data Donation Module (Pfiffner et al., 2022) (different measurements, different platforms)
Dona (Hakobyan et al., 2025) (messaging data, different platforms)
WhatsR (Kohne & Montag, 2024) (messaging data, WhatsApp)

section: Step I.II: How do I anonymize data? üôà
text:
Step I.II: How do I anonymize data? üôà
Good anonymization may require‚Ä¶


Whitelists/dictionaries of social media accounts

Database of public speakers, Hans-Bredow-Institute (Link)
Database of news media and their social media handles, University of Vienna (Link)

Local, in-tool classification (e.g., topic modeling)
Manual annotation (e.g., type of contact)
Aggregation

For this research question, what are (dis-)advantages of each sample? ü§î

(think about characteristics of the sample, response rates, representativeness, etc.)

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
section: Step I.III: How do I integrate the tool in surveys & recruit participants?
text:
Step I.III: How do I integrate the tool in surveys & recruit participants?


Use a single platform for survey & data donation
Think about characteristics of your population, e.g.,

Who is using the platform where data should be donated from?
Who is willing and able to share their data?
Can you incentive participants in a meaningful way?

‚ö†Ô∏è Often, the main goal will not (or cannot) be to reach a ‚Äúrepresentative‚Äù sample.

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
section: Step I.III: How do I integrate the tool in surveys & recruit participants?
text:
Step I.III: How do I integrate the tool in surveys & recruit participants?


Low response rates (e.g., Hase & Haim, 2024; Keusch et al., 2024)

Behavioral intentions as ‚Äúwillingness to donate‚Äù high (79-52% of survey respondents)
Actual behavior as ‚Äúparticipation in data donation‚Äù low (38-1% of survey respondents)
Well known intention-behavior gap (Kmetty & Stefkovics, 2025)

Manual annotation (by participants or researchers)

Text-as-data methods

Download the ‚ÄúData for Task 5‚Äù from the website. It contains YouTube searches from a German social media sample. Either discuss this conceptually or try this in R/Python‚Ä¶..

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
section: Step II.II: How do I check for bias?
text:
Step II.II: How do I check for bias?

Errors in representation and measurements

based on systematic drop-out (Pak et al., 2022)
based on systematic misclassification of digital traces (TeBlunthuis et al., 2024)


üëâ You know the drill: We will talk about this in session 4Ô∏è‚É£.

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
text:
Step III: Modelling

Figure. Data donation study - researcher perspective

title: Data Donation Tutorial DGPuK RezFo
section: Step III.I: How do I analyze results?
text:
Step III.I: How do I analyze results?
For inferential modeling, consider (Clemm Von Hohenberg et al., 2024)‚Ä¶.


Creating indices from different metrics (e.g., liking, sharing, or commenting) and testing their consistency
Accounting for missing data (units, measures)
Skewed data (e.g., zero-inflation) and non-linear relationships
Hierarchical structure (nested in participants, metrics, platforms) and within/between variance
Advanced longitudinal approaches (e.g., with respect to sequences, feedback loops and causal inference)
